title: How to sell a product that hasn't been made - Quora

response.answer_text: Your question initially refers to a “product” in such a way that implies (to me) that you’re already an established company delivering products/services and you need to start selling something new to a customer base. That part is pretty simple. But the explanation of your question seems to get more into launching product line or suite or products (or even a company like Microsoft based primarily on a product line), which is very difficult. As a Product Manager who has taken pre-orders for products months or longer before delivery, I will respond to the prior interpretation of the question. If launching a single product, even before it’s built or deliverable, you can worry less about selling yourself or marketing or websites or some of the other aspects discussed in other responses. Sure, salesmanship helps, but it’s critical. This assumes you have at least some reasonable reputation of delivering on promises. Kevin Smith was the closest to what I would answer out of the current lot.  If you have truly found a market problem to solve, and have truly solved that problem (in the mind of the end user, not just yourself), then all you really need to do is be able to articulate that pain point to the customer and confidently show how you have removed/lessened it. You don’t even have to articulate the actual pain point much – if it’s really that painful the customer will be well aware – you just need to sell the fact that you “get it” and are capable of fixing it, then show how. In many cases, you really don’t even have to “show” how you fixed it – if you’ve found the sweet spot where pain point meets price point, it will sell itself.  A long time ago, we had alarm clocks that you had to set every night or remember to turn off on days you didn’t want it to wake you. If you’ve ever been late to work because you forgot to set the alarm on, or if you keep waking up early on Saturdays because you forgot to turn off the alarm the night before, then when I pitch you an alarm clock that can be set to only wake you up on work days, you would automatically see the value. You would probably sign up for it before it was shippable. You may even do so before asking how much it costs, because it can’t cost more than a missed day of work, right?   If you’ve done your homework and have actually solved a problem, you likely won’t have to try that hard to sell it.

When you present a product/service the first thing that you are selling is yourself, your technical abilities to have the job done, your accountability to reach what you promise, your desire to live to reach what you promise, to mantain promises and dedicate all the time you have to the project you are presenting.Generally investors prefer teams that offer more guarantees to dedicate full time to the project but, very very important, a team that works together, that has technical knowledge needed, that help each other.All these aspects are more important that forecast, planning and number that are based on hypothetical environment and situations.After this consider that a product that is not yet represented by something material should solve a problem, pain or be something useful for people before they understand the need of your product.

You should always sell it in some way before you build it. I say in some way, as selling can go from convincing people about the value you're adding to having a binding sale commitment. Now, you have to decide the optimized effort vs. time combination you need to convince your prospects. Do you need a :- 5min oral pitch?- 10 slides presentation?- 2-week work MVP? That's your call. My advice is to start with the former, test it, and then progress to the latter. I hope you'll find the validation you're seeking.

Verify that there is a real problem that has to be solved.  When I look at buyer personas I focus on the problem, what causes the problem, and the impact of that problem.  If you can understand the business problem, and what the financial impact is (ie- it's costing sales, or creating expenses), and you can address it with your proposed solution you can test to see if this is something your target would pay for.

I am currently in th process of running in parallel the development (of a couple of products) with the research on the marketability of the same. I use social media to get feed-back on what people want but also on how they react to my ideas. You have to be subtle on how you ask. People like to give their opinion. Many times you encounter hostility to your ideas so you have to find out how to deal with this. I use my contact with 'the people' to apply it to the design and also to gather an audience for the product. A business or major partner is reluctant to consider your idea unless you bring proof of its performance and feed-back from potential users. Some company bosses are very demanding and they want to see that you are already selling it, let alone making it.

Make videos about it, try to convince your future customers that they need it and also you will need to build a brand (try these tips for that 3 Most Valuable Branding Tips For Startups - Blurred Mag), all is done in some crowdfunding company.

One simple step would be to create a website that explains the idea and lets users enter their email address to be notified when its available.  If you get good traffic to the page and a reasonable percentage of users entering their email then you can be more confident there is a real market for your business.  The additional benefit of course is if you do make the product, you have a ready made list of interested customers.
Try sites like KickStarter - for advanced bookings and crowd funding.I believe that's what you are looking for. Please let me know if it helps.
The hardest aspect is selling yourself as a qualified supplier.  Individuals or startups have an enormous task over-coming that barrier.  It can be done, and has been done many times.
